sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• usual dosage 400 mg orally every 6 hours; may titrate up to 4 g per day based on infection severity; may also give one-half total daily dose every 12 hours or one-third total daily dose every 8 hours
  • Bartonellosis - HIV infection: (bacillary angiomatosis, peliosis hepatis, bacteremia, osteomyelitis) 500 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for at least 3 months
  • Chlamydial infection: 800 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for 7 days (guideline dosing) or 800 mg ORALLY 3 times daily for 7 days (manufacturer dosing)
  • Chlamydia trachomatis infection - Genitourinary chlamydia infection - Pregnancy: 800 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for 7 days or 400 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for 14 days (guideline dosing) OR 800 mg ORALLY 3 times daily for 7 days (manufacturer dosing)
  • Diphtheria, To antitoxin; Adjunct: 400 mg ORALLY every 6 hr; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Erythrasma: 400 mg ORALLY every 6 hr; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Female gonococcal pelvic inflammatory disease: 400 mg ORALLY every 6 hr; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Impetigo: (Staphylococcus and Streptococcus species) 400 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for 7 days, depending on clinical response (guideline dosing)
  • Infection due to Entamoeba histolytica - Intestinal infectious disease: 400 mg ORALLY four times daily for 10 to 14 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue (Mild to Moderate), Caused by S. pyogenes or S. aureus: 400 mg ORALLY every 6 hr; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Legionnaires disease: 1.6 to 4 g ORALLY daily in divided doses
  • Listeriosis: 400 mg ORALLY every 6 hr; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Lyme disease: (alternative to first-line) 500 mg ORALLY four times daily for 14 to 21 days for early localized or early disseminated Lyme disease associated with erythema migrans, or borrelial lymphocytoma
  • Nongonococcal urethritis: 800 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for 7 days (guideline dosing) or 800 mg ORALLY 3 times daily for 7 days (manufacturer dosing)
  • Pertussis: 40 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in divided doses for 5 to 14 days; or 2 g/day ORALLY in 4 divided doses for 14 days (guideline dosing)
  • Primary syphilis, In penicillin allergic patients: 48 to 64 g ORALLY in divided doses over a period of 10 to 15 days
  • Respiratory tract infection: 400 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or may give one-half the daily dose every 12 hours or one-third the daily dose every 8 hours (twice-daily dosing not recommended for doses above 1 g/day); MAX 4 g/day
  • Rheumatic fever, In penicillin allergic patients; Prophylaxis: 400 mg ORALLY every 6 h; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection for 10 days

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• usual dosage 30 to 50 mg/kg/day orally in equally divided doses every 6 hours; dose may be doubled for more severe infections; may be given as one-half total daily dose every 12 hours or one-third total daily dose every 8 hours
  • Bartonellosis - HIV infection: (cutaneous bacillary angiomatosis) 30 to 50 mg/kg/day (MAX 2 g/day) ORALLY divided into 2 to 4 doses/day for 3 months
  • Chlamydial infection: (children less than 45 kg) 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 4 doses daily for 14 days
  • Chlamydia trachomatis infection - Genitourinary chlamydia infection - Pregnancy: 800 mg ORALLY 3 times daily for 7 days
  • Diphtheria, To antitoxin; Adjunct: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in equally divided doses every 6 hours; dosage may be doubled for more severe infections, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Erythrasma: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in equally divided doses every 6 hours; dosage may be doubled for more severe infections
  • Female gonococcal pelvic inflammatory disease: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in equally divided doses every 6 hours; dosage may be doubled for more severe infections
  • Infection due to Entamoeba histolytica - Intestinal infectious disease: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in divided doses for 10 to 14 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue (Mild to Moderate), Caused by S. pyogenes or S. aureus: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in equally divided doses every 6 hours; dosage may be doubled for more severe infections
  • Listeriosis: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in equally divided doses every 6 hr; dosage may be doubled for more severe infections
  • Lyme disease: (alternative to first-line) 12.5 mg/kg ORALLY four times daily for 14 to 21 days for early localized or early disseminated Lyme disease associated with erythema migrans, or borrelial lymphocytoma; maximum daily dose, 2000 mg
  • Neonatal chlamydial conjunctivitis: 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in 4 divided doses for 14 days
  • Neonatal chlamydial pneumonia: 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 4 doses daily for 14 days; dosage may be doubled for more severe infections
  • Pertussis: 40 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in divided doses for 5 to 14 days; 14 days preferred to avoid risk for relapse; MAX 2 g/day; use not recommended if younger than 1 month (alternative is azithromycin)
  • Primary syphilis, In penicillin allergic patients: 48 to 64 g ORALLY in divided doses over a period of 10 to 15 days
  • Respiratory tract infection: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided every 6 to 12 hours (2, 3, or 4 divided doses) for mild to moderate infections; may double the dose for severe infections
  • Respiratory tract infection: community-acquired pneumonia; older than 3 months of age) 40 mg/kg/day ORALLY in 4 divided doses (guideline dosing)
  • Rheumatic fever, In penicillin allergic patients; Prophylaxis: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in equally divided doses every 6 h for 10 days; dosage may be doubled for more severe infections

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: hepatic impairment: drug may accumulate in patients with severe liver disease; no specific dosing recommendations available

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• concomitant therapy with astemizole, cisapride, pimozide, or terfenadine
  • concomitant use with ergotamine or dihydroergotamine
  • hypersensitivity to erythromycin or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• diarrhea (sometimes Clostridium difficile-associated), ranging in severity from mild diarrhea to fatal colitis, has been reported and may occur as late as 2 months or more after discontinuation; if occurs while still using, discontinuation may be necessary
  • elderly; potentially increased risk of erythromycin-associated hearing loss (especially with renal or hepatic dysfunction), QT-interval prolongation, and torsade de pointes
  • hepatic dysfunction (eg, increased liver enzymes, and hepatocellular and/or cholestatic hepatitis, with or without jaundice) has been reported
  • hepatic function, impaired; risk of toxicity
  • infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) has been reported
  • myasthenia gravis, exacerbation, and new-onset myasthenic syndrome have been reported
  • pregnant women with early syphilis; oral erythromycin treatment may not reach the fetus adequately to prevent congenital syphilis
  • prolonged or repeated use; overgrowth of nonsusceptible bacteria or fungi (ie, superinfection) may occur; discontinuation recommended
  • QT prolongation has been reported, including cases of arrhythmia, torsade de pointes, and death; avoid use with known QT-interval prolongation, ongoing proarrhythmic conditions (eg, uncorrected hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia), clinically significant bradycardia, and concomitant use with Class IA (quinidine, procainamide) or Class III (dofetilide, amiodarone, sotalol) antiarrhythmics

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Erythromycin: AAP: Maternal medication usually compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Erythromycin: WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Erythromycin: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain, Diarrhea, Loss of appetite, Nausea, Vomiting
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Torsades de pointes, Ventricular tachycardia
  • Dermatologic:Erythema multiforme, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Gastrointestinal:Acquired hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, infantile (5%), Pancreatitis, Pseudomembranous enterocolitis
  • Hepatic:Decreased liver function
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Neurologic:Seizure
  • Renal:Interstitial nephritis

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Erythromycin ethylsuccinate is a macrolide antibiotic derived from the strain of Saccharopolyspora erythraea. It inhibits protein synthesis by binding 50 S ribosomal subunits of susceptible microorganisms but does not affect nucleic acid synthesis.

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Fecal
  • Renal: less than 5% in active form
  • Dialyzable: no (hemodialysis); no (peritoneal dialysis)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • may be given without regard to meals
  • (suspension) shake well before measuring each dose
  • (suspension) after reconstitution, use within 35 days; no refrigeration required

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• symptomatic improvement
  • hepatic function
  • hearing exam (hearing loss, especially with high doses and renal or hepatic insufficiency)
  • gonococcal acute pelvic inflammatory disease (penicillin sensitive patients): serologic test for syphilis before and 3 months after treatment

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
OVERDOSE: Significant toxicity following acute overdose is uncommon. N/V, abdominal pain may occur. ADVERSE EFFECTS: N/V, abdominal pain, diarrhea most common. Cholestasis, sensorineural hearing loss, thrombophlebitis (IV administration), ventricular dysrhythmias/QT prolongation (IV administration) are less common.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal, gastric lavage.
  • Support: Therapy as indicated.
  • Abdominal discomfort: Food, milk or an antacid may be given; most effects reverse with drug cessation
  • Monitoring of patient: Baseline ECG, cardiac monitoring as indicated. Renal and hepatic function as indicated.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
In general, the macrolide antibiotics are of a low order toxicity.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may cause dose-related nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and anorexia.
  • Advise parents or caregivers of infant patients to immediately report symptoms of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS), such as vomiting or irritability with feeding.
  • Instruct patient to immediately report watery and bloody stools (with or without stomach cramps and fever) that occurs during therapy; may also occur as late as 2 months after drug discontinuation.
  • Advise patient there are multiple significant drug-drug interactions for this drug. Consult healthcare professional prior to new drug use (including over-the-counter and herbal drugs).
